attributes.title: Examining the Conceptual and Empirical Distinctiveness of Agreeableness and “Dark” Personality Items

q1.value: Examining the Conceptual and Empirical Distinctiveness of Agreeableness and “Dark” Personality Items

q2.value: Colin Vize, Josh Miller, Donald Lynam

q3.value: A growing research literature has focused on what have been termed “dark” personality traits/constructs. This literature includes work on the Dark Triad (Paulhus & Williams, 2002), Dark Tetrad (Buckels et al., 2013), and the more recently studied “dark factor” of personality (Moshagen et al., 2018). Sadism, psychopathy, Machiavellianism, narcissism, spitefulness, and egoism are a handful of the traits/constructs that have been the focus of the dark factor research which has been broader in scope than research on the Dark Triad/Tetrad. To date, no work has rigorously investigated whether the dark factor can be captured by existing models of normative personality, namely agreeableness from the Five-factor model and honesty-humility from the HEXACO model. The primary purpose of the present study is to examine whether the dark factor of personality can be conceptually and empirically understood as a personality construct at the opposite pole of agreeableness and honesty-humility.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: The traits assessed by the newly developed D70 measure of the dark factor of personality (Moshagen et al., 2019) can be understood as traits related to (low) agreeableness/honesty-humility. As such, a joint factor analysis of agreeableness-related items and dark factor items will yield a factor structure similar to the structure observed for agreeableness-related items (e.g., Crowe et al., 2018) with the factors being composed of both agreeableness and D-70 items. 

Hypothesis 2: We expect that the shared variance among the scales of the D70 is essentially isomorphic with the shared variance among the scales identified to make up the hierarchical structure of agreeableness (Crowe et al., 2018). Thus, the estimated latent correlation between a latent agreeableness factor and a latent dark personality factor will approach unity (i.e., ≥ |.90 |).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit our sample from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) platform. We will not include any MTurker qualifications (e.g., 95% HIT approval rating) given work that has shown that typically used MTurk qualifications do not necessarily increase data quality and may have deleterious effects (Robinson et al., 2019). Participants will first complete a brief prescreen item that will ask, “What are the steps to taking a drink from a drinking fountain?” Participants who provide a correct answer to the question that demonstrates an understanding of the question will be invited to complete the survey portion of the study. Participants will read a brief description of the HIT which provides the payment amount and the estimated time to completion. Once agreeing to complete the study, participants will be provided with a Qualtrics survey link which will take them to the Qualtrics website to complete the protocol. The order of survey completion will be determined randomly for each participant. 

Once participants have completed the entirety of the protocol, they will be provided with a completion code which they will enter on the MTurk workers platform in order to receive payment for their participation. Participants will be paid $3.50 for completion of the survey, and $0.25 cents for the completion of the pre-screen short answer.

q13.value: We plan to have a final sample size (i.e., after all data screening has been completed) of approximately 500 participants.

q14.value: Recent simulation based research has provided evidence that in realistic scenarios, a sample size ≥500 is needed if commonly used extraction criteria are used to determine the number of factors to extract, but there is some disagreement among the criteria (Auerswald & Moshagen, 2019). Though we do not a priori expect divergent results for our different extraction criteria, we plan to have a large enough sample to handle the issue should it arise.

q15.value: Once we have met our preregistered sample size goal (N ≈ 500), we will not collect any more data.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated.

Demographic Information: Items assessing age, gender, ethnicity, and education level will be administered.

D-70: The D-70 is a 70 item measure assessing various “dark” traits that constitute what has been termed the “dark core” of personality. All items will be assessed using a 1-5 Likert scale, ranging from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree.” There is also a 22-item form, which uses a subset of 22 items from the D-70.   

Agreeableness Items: A total of 104 agreeableness-related items will be administered. These items are drawn from a recent empirical investigation of the hierarchical structure of the agreeableness domain (Crowe et al., 2018). The 104 self-report items were drawn from 22 different agreeableness related scales, and evidence showed that the 104 items could be organized into five factors: Compassion, Morality, Trust, Affability, and Modesty. All items will be assessed using a 1-5 Likert scale, ranging from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree.”

IPIP-NEO-120: The IPIP-NEO-120 is a freely available 120-item measure of the Five-factor model of personality. 5 domain scales and 30 facet scales can be scored using the measure. Of the 24 agreeableness items from the IPIP-NEO-120, 14 will be used for the agreeableness measure described above. All items will be assessed using a 1-5 Likert scale, ranging from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree.” 

HEXACO-PI-R-100: A total of 32 items from the Honesty-Humility and Agreeableness scales of the HEXACO-PI-R will be administered. Of these 32 items, 24 will be used for the agreeableness measures described above. All items will be assessed using a 1-5 Likert scale, ranging from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree.”

Reactive-Proactive Aggression Questionnaire: The Reactive Proactive Aggression Questionnaire (RPQ) is a 23-item self-report measure which measures both reactive and proactive aggression. Items will be rated on a three point scale, by choosing either 0 (never), 1 (sometimes), or 2 (often).

Crime and Analogous Behavior Scale: We will administer 17 items from the CAB, a self-report measure that asks respondents whether or not they have engaged in a range of activities (yes/no) and the frequency of such activities (0 times to 6 times). Items assess a variety of externalizing behaviors including substance use, aggression, and non-violent antisocial behavior (e.g., theft).

Externalizing Behavior Scales: To create scales that assess antisocial behavior, we will use variety scores based on items from the Crime and Analogous Behavior (CAB) scale. The substance use variety scale will be created from 5 substance use items based on yes/no endorsement such that scores can range from 0-5. The antisocial behavior variety scale will be created from 10 items based on yes/no endorsement such that scores can range from 0-10. Single items will be used to asses binge drinking frequency in the last month, and marijuana use frequency in the last month. For the two frequency items, participant responses can range from 0 to 6 or more times.

Statistical Model for Hypothesis 1: To test hypothesis 1, we will conduct a joint, “bass-ackwards” factor analysis of the 70 items from the D-70 and the 104 agreeableness items. The “bass-ackwards” approach can be completed using either principal components or principle factor analysis. We will make use of principle factor analysis while using the principal axis method for factor extraction. We will also apply a promax rotation to extracted factor solutions, given the expected correlations among the factors. The statistical model described here is the same as the factor model used in Crowe et al. (2018) when identifying the hierarchical structure of agreeableness traits. The “bass-ackwards” analyses will be conducted using the ‘psych’ package in R.  

Statistical Model for Hypothesis 2: To test hypothesis 2, we will estimate a structural equation model. The model will include two latent factors—a dark personality factor and an agreeableness factor. The dark personality factor will be modeled using the 12 scales of the D-70. The agreeableness latent factor will be modeled using the 5 factor scales computed from the 104 agreeableness items. The primary metric of interest is the latent correlation between the two latent factors of dark personality and agreeableness. Both unstandardized and standardized loadings/latent relations will be reported. The model will be estimated using the ‘lavaan’ package in R. 

Though our primary analyses will be focused on the D-70, we will also conduct the same analyses using the 22-item short form designed to more succinctly assess dark traits. When using the 22-item form to test Hypothesis 2, the latent factor will be modeled based on the individual items as opposed to specific subscales.

q20.value: It is likely that our measures of antisocial behavior (the CAB and RPQ scales) will be non-normally distributed. Because these variables will be used as outcomes in our exploratory regression analyses, they will be log-transformed prior to the regression analyses.

q21.value:
Inference Criteria for Hypothesis 1: Because the “bass-ackwards” approach is an iterative process where one can continue to extract as many factors as there are items, we will use both conceptual and empirical criteria for determining when factor extraction will stop. Our empirical criteria for factor extraction will be parallel analysis (PA), Velicer’s minimum average partial (MAP) test, and/or when there is a factor on which no item has its highest factor loading. Regarding PA, the number of factors to extract will be determined by how many factors can be extracted with eigenvalues greater than those found for randomly generated data. For MAP, the number of factors to extract will be based on the factor solution that has the smallest MAP value (i.e., the average squared partial correlation reaches its lowest value). 

Separate from the empirical factor extraction criteria, we will not extract factors when a factor is either too specific to be meaningful or is no longer interpretable. In cases where these criteria may conflict (e.g., a factor can be extracted where items have their strongest loading but is difficult to interpret), we will give more weight to the conceptual criterion, as interpretability of the factors is essential. These inferential criteria are in line with general recommendations for the “bass-ackwards” approach (Goldberg, 2006), and were used in the original Crowe et al. (2018) article.

After applying the factor extraction methods, our inference criteria for determining a shared hierarchical structure of agreeableness and dark personality items will be that the “bass-ackwards” factor solution will not produce interpretable factors (i.e., factors that are not overly narrow or a methodological factor) that are composed solely of agreeableness or dark personality items. In other words, the factors produced at every level of the “bass-ackwards” hierarchy should be composed of both agreeableness and dark personality items in order for us to infer that the items are assessing the same latent factors.

Inference Criteria for Hypothesis 2: Our primary index of interest in our statistical model of Hypothesis 2 is the latent correlation between the dark personality latent factor and the agreeableness latent factor. In order to conclude that the shared variance among agreeableness scales and dark personality scales is approximately isomorphic, we will take a latent correlation ≥ |".90" | as support for such a conclusion.

q22.value:
We plan to exclude data that show evidence of invalid/careless responding. In order to exclude such data, we plan to use 4 steps to ensure data quality:

1)	Participants who provide invalid answers to our prescreen item described above (“What are the steps for drinking water from a water fountain”) will be excluded from completing the survey portion of the study. Though there are no strict criteria for what constitutes an invalid answer, we expect participants to demonstrate an understanding of the question (they respond with information that is relevant to drinking water from a water fountain) and be generally accurate. At minimum, this would involve writing about pushing a button/lever/bar and bending over to drink the water. The first author will review the responses and rate the responses for validity (yes/no). Second and third authors will be consulted if there are responses that are not clearly right or wrong and majority vote will determine whether to invite the participant to complete the full study. Participants with responses rated as invalid will be excluded from participating in the survey portion of the study.

2)	Three Attention check items will be administered. E.g., Click the circle that says “Strongly Agree.”  

Three Re-captcha items will be administered. These are easy to answer open-ended questions (e.g., What is 2+4?). 

A failure of two or more of the six attention check and re-captcha items will result in rejection. 

3)	The estimated amount of time to complete the protocol is approximately 20-45 minutes. Thus, completion times faster than 10 minutes will result in that data not being included in analyses. 

4)	Two validity scales (Too Good to be True and Infrequency; 8 items each) from the original EPA (Lynam et al., 2011) will be administered to participants. Example items include “I have never in my life been angry at another person” and “I try to eat something almost every day.” Participants’ data will be considered invalid if their responses for either scale are 2.75 standard deviations above the sample average.

Steps 2 and 3 will be applied to responses before payment, so work will be rejected and no payment given if participant data do not meet these requirements. Step 4 will be applied after the work has been accepted and payment has been sent.

q23.value: A necessary condition for participant data to be included is that MTurk participants complete the entirety of the survey in order to receive a Qualtrics completion code that they will then enter to have their work approved. Thus, we do not expect any missing data.

q24.value:
In addition to our primary confirmatory hypotheses, we plan to conduct exploratory hypotheses to examine the potential incremental predictive validity of the dark personality traits beyond the agreeableness traits. These analyses will make use of the Reactive-Proactive Aggression scales (proactive and reactive), and the CAB antisocial behavior variety scale. 

These exploratory analyses will make use of hierarchical multiple regression models. Three models will be examined with RPQ-Reactive aggression, RPQ-Proactive Aggression, and CAB-Antisocial Variety serving as the DVs for the three respective models. Standardized latent factor scores estimated from the agreeableness and dark personality scales will serve as the predictor variables. At step 1, the standardized latent factor scores for agreeableness will be entered. At step 2, the standardized latent factor scores for dark personality will be entered. We will examine the change in R2 at step 2 of the models to see how much incremental validity is accounted for in our antisocial behavior variables when the dark personality traits are added to the model. Latent factor scores will be estimated using the regression method in ‘lavaan’. 

We will also conduct analyses to better understand the content of the agreeableness factors at each level of the hierarchy identified by the “bass-ackwards” solution. These analyses will be conducted by correlating the agreeableness factors from the “bass-ackwards” solution with the subscales of the D70, the agreeableness subscales from which the agreeableness items were drawn from, the remaining IPIP-NEO-120 facet scales (i.e., facet scales from the N,E,O, and C domains), and the five optimal factors originally identified in Crowe et al. (2018).

q25.value: Because we expect there to be a good deal of overlap among the dark personality and agreeableness items, preregistered item retention rules will be followed in order to reduce the chance of extracting bloated specific factors. Specifically, we will examine the zero-order correlations among all agreeableness and dark personality items using a cutoff of a correlation  ≥ |.65| to identify redundant items. When selecting which item to remove from redundant pairs, the item with more redundancies will be removed. For example, if Item 1 and Item 2 are redundant (r ≥ |.65|), but Item 1 only has one redundancy while Item 2 is also redundant with Item 3, Item 2 will be removed. Thus, two redundancies will be removed by dropping one item. If items have the same number of redundancies, the item to be dropped will be chosen randomly. The |.65| both maximizes item content and minimizes the risk of bloated specific factors. This process of item removal/retention was used in Crowe et al. (2018).

Both unstandardized and standardized loadings/latent relations will be reported. The model will be estimated using the ‘lavaan’ package in R. 

Though our primary analyses will be focused on the D-70, we will also conduct the same analyses using the 22-item short form designed to more succinctly assess dark traits. When using the 22-item form to test Hypothesis 2, the latent factor will be modeled based on the individual items as opposed to specific subscales.

attributes.title: The efficacy and safety of acupuncture for perimenopause symptom compared with different sham acupuncture control groups

q1.value: The efficacy and safety of acupuncture for perimenopause symptom compared with different sham acupuncture control groups

q2.value: Qiujun He, Feng Zhang, Yanqiu Wang, Sanyin Zhang

q4.value:
Perimenopause syndrome, referred also as a climacteric syndrome, The perimenopausal symptoms include premenopause, menopause and postmenopause.  Perimenopause is a normal and important aging phenomenon that occurs in women’s life. Although some women have no obvious symptoms during this period, Most women still suffer from perimenopausal symptoms that affect health, work, life, and economic status. The most common and frequent episode of perimenopausal symptoms is hot flashes, which affect around 75% of menopausal women, In addition, the incidence of menopause insomnia is as high as 39% –47%, Other symptoms include anxiety, fatigue, irritability, weight gain, night sweats, vaginal dryness, and urinary incontinence. These perimenopausal symptoms begin 1–2 years before menopause and may persist from 6 months to more than ten years. These menopause symptoms may be caused by the perimenopause itself, or it may be a chain reaction caused by one of them. These chain reactions may cause or promote the occurrence of diseases such as high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular diseases, psychological diseases and so on while accelerating aging. Hot flashes can affect women's work and quality of life, Of course, sleep will also be affected. In addition, hard to falling sleep has been shown to associate strongly with anxiety, Insomnia and anxiety of menopausal women have a chain effect and cause depression. So it can be seen that the symptoms of perimenopause are not single, there may be multiple symptoms. It may even promote or cause other diseases. 
What is the cause of such a wide-ranging, long-lasting disease? The etiology of perimenopausal syndrome, which is now known to be due to the decline or disappearance of ovarian function, hormone levels fluctuations, and instability. Therefore, hormone replacement therapy has become the most effective treatment for the perimenopausal syndrome. But the Women’s Health Initiative (WHI) reported an increase in cases of Cardiovascular disease after hormone therapy. Considering the duration of perimenopausal symptoms, hormones are not suitable for long-term use. Therefore, more people choose to try non-hormonal replacement therapy, acupuncture is one of them. Acupuncture treatments include traditional hand acupuncture, electroacupuncture, ear acupuncture, laser acupuncture, acupressure, moxibustion, etc. Research reports that acupuncture can relieve perimenopausal symptoms and improve quality of life. Although according to research reports that the efficacy of acupuncture has obvious advantages compared with the waiting group or the usual care controls, it also has certain effects compared with western medicine control, it compared with fake acupuncture is highly controversial. The related meta-analysis studies also showed it. A meta-analysis study by Weihan Li et al. Showed that The number of RCTs that compared the acupuncture control to a sham group is too small, and some studies had a flawed methodology, making it difficult for them to generate reliable conclusions about the efficacy of acupuncture. Therefore, the systematic review and meta-analysis hope to further analyze the efficacy and safety of acupuncture in the treatment of perimenopausal symptoms, focusing on the analysis of different acupuncture interventions and different controls, especially sham acupuncture controls.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Method The protocol followed Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Protocols. RCT study on different acupuncture interventions for perimenopausal symptoms will be searched in 8 databases (PubMed, EMBASE, the Cochrane Library, the web of science, CBM, CNKI, WAN FANG, and VIP). Besides, the search will also be performed on the clinical trial research platform if necessary. The primary outcome that will be extracted：the Flushes per 24 hours, the Frequency of hot flashes, the severity of hot flashes, the menopause-related symptom score, the treatment efficacy，the adverse event. Endnote software X8 will be used for study selection, STATA 13.0 and Review Manager software 5.3 will be used for analysis and synthesis. These studies selection, data extraction, and risk of bias assessment will be conducted by two independent reviewers.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: The protocol followed Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Protocols. RCT study on different acupuncture interventions for perimenopausal symptoms will be searched in 8 databases (PubMed, EMBASE, the Cochrane Library, the web of science, CBM, CNKI, WAN FANG, and VIP). Besides, the search will also be performed on the clinical trial research platform if necessary. The primary outcome that will be extracted：the Flushes per 24 hours, the Frequency of hot flashes, the severity of hot flashes, the menopause-related symptom score, the treatment efficacy，the adverse event. Endnote software X8 will be used for study selection

The conﬁdence intervals (CIs) will be set to 95% for both continuous outcomes and dichotomous outcomes. The dichotomous outcomes (the effective rate and adverse events) will analyze the rate ratio. For continuous variables, the mean and SD of the change value were will calculate according to the baseline value and endpoint value of the extracted data. If the included data is not mean and SD, calculate and analyze according to the formula.

the fixed effects model will be used for the analysis of this outcome indicator，when It's heterogeneity test result is I2 < 50%(No heterogeneity). if the heterogeneity test result is I2 ≥ 50%（have heterogeneity）, after excluding obvious clinical and methodological heterogeneity, the random-effects model will be used for the analysis of this outcome indicator.

attributes.title: Confirmation bias and degraded audio recordings

q1.value: Confirmation bias in interpreting and evaluating degraded forensic audio evidence

q2.value: Megan E. Giroux, Daniel M Bernstein, Deb Connolly

q3.value: There is preliminary evidence that contextual information can influence people's interpretation of degraded audio recordings. Specifically, learning that recordings come from criminal suspects' interviews makes people more likely to interpret innocuous recordings as incriminating. However, no research has investigated whether presenting additional contextual information increases this effect. Therefore, the goal of this study is to determine whether additional contextual information that further suggests the speaker's involvement in criminal activity increases the tendency for people to make incriminating misinterpretations while listening to innocuous recordings.

q4.value: I expect that participants who receive two pieces of contextual information about the recordings (i.e., that the recordings come from wire-tapped conversations with criminal suspects that have been used as evidence in criminal trials in which there were also eyewitnesses who identified the accused persons from line-ups) will make more incriminating misinterpretations than participants who receive only one piece of contextual information about the recordings (i.e., that the recordings come from wire-tapped conversations with criminal suspects that have been used as evidence in criminal trials); participants who receive only one piece of contextual information about the recordings will make more incriminating misinterpretations than participants who receive no contextual information about the recordings.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Because the study will be run through an online platform, participants will be randomly assigned to conditions by the program.

question.value: This study is a one-factor between-subject design with three levels. The factor is the type of contextual information that participants receive and the three levels are: (1) no contextual information about the recordings; (2) the recordings come from wiretapped conversations with criminal suspects that have been used as evidence in criminal trials; and (3) the recordings come from wire-tapped conversations with criminal suspects that have been used as evidence in criminal trials in which there were also eyewitnesses who identified the accused persons from line-ups.

q9.value: We will use simple random sampling to assign participants to 1 of the 3 levels of the independent variable.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit participants through Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) as well as through our psychology undergraduate research pool. Given that our stimuli are forensically relevant and therefore potentially upsetting to some participants, we will restrict our sample of MTurk participants to those individuals living in Canada or the USA in order to provide them with the appropriate information for resources they should contact if they feel upset after participating in our study. Additionally, participants must be able to speak English fluently and must not have any serious hearing problems that impede their ability to listen to the audio recordings. Furthermore, any individuals who participated in our pilot studies will not be permitted to participate in this study given that we are using the same stimuli. Finally, all participants who have a 95% approval rating, who have successfully completed at least 100 tasks on MTurk, and who are able to correctly respond to an initial Captcha (Completely Automated Public Turing Test to tell Computers and Humans Apart) Verification will be permitted to participate. In the Captchta Verification, participants will have to look at an image and then answer a question about what is in the image. The reason that we use these inclusion criteria is because of an increased prevalence of "bots" on MTurk. Using these inclusions will allow us to filter out these bots.

Once participants sign up for our study, they will either be able to click on a link which will re-direct them to a Qualtrics page where they can complete the study (for MTurk participants), or we will send them a link which will take them to the Qualtrics page where they can complete the study (for research pool participants). We anticipate being able to collect data more quickly through MTurk than through the undergraduate research pool. Therefore, we will post slots for this study in blocks so that we have relatively the same number of participants from the community sample and the student sample completing the study during the same time period (e.g., we will post 30 MTurk timeslots and 30 research pool timeslots per week until we collect our required number of participants). Participants recruited through MTurk will receive $3.00 USD for their participation while participants recruited through the research pool will receive course credit for their participation.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 390 participants.  Based on previous research using MTurk, we expect about 8-10% unusable data (Fleischhut, Meder, & Gigerenzer, 2017). To ensure enough usable data, we will aim to recruit 430 participants.

q14.value: We conducted an a priori power analysis in G*Power 3.1 to determine the sample size required for Study 1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009). Previous research has demonstrated a medium effect of incriminating contextual information on participants’ incriminating misinterpretations of recordings (OR = 4.56; Lange et al., 2011, Experiment 1). However, given the new stimuli and different contextual information, we will be more conservative and assume a small-to-medium effect. Thus, with f = .2, α = .05, Power = .95, and number of groups = 3, we require a sample of N = 390.

q15.value: We will post participant time slots at the beginning of each week, with 30 MTurk time slots and 30 research pool time slots posted each week. We will do this until we reach our target sample size of 430.

question.value:
We will manipulate the amount of contextual information that participants receive about the recordings they will hear. This is the only independent variable in the current study, and has 3 levels:
(1) No contextual information about the recordings
(2) The recordings come from wiretapped conversations with criminal suspects that have been used as evidence in criminal trials 
(3) The recordings come from wire-tapped conversations with criminal suspects that have been used as evidence in criminal trials in which there were also eyewitnesses who identified the accused persons from line-ups.

The main dependent variable is the proportion of incriminating misinterpretations that participants make. We will measure this by counting the number of incriminating misinterpretations that participants make and dividing this number by the total number of statements they transcribe (i.e., if they make 8 incriminating misinterpretations out of the 48 statements they transcribe, the proportion of incriminating misinterpretations will be 8/48  = .16). 

We will also include participants' performance on the LexTale (a measure of English language proficiency) as a covariate. Participants see a series of 60 words (e.g., “recipient”) and nonwords (e.g., “exprate”) and simply indicate whether the target is a word or nonword. Participants’ responses are scored as the average number of items answered correctly, calculated as: ((number of words correct/40*100) + (number of nonwords correct/20*100)) / 2.  

Finally, we will include two additional measures of participants’ transcriptions that we will use in exploratory analyses: (1) the proportion of accurate identifications that participants make (transcriptions in which participants correctly identify every word in a given statement) and (2) the proportion of non-incriminating errors that participants make (transcriptions in which participants incorrectly identify one or more of the words in a given statement in a manner that is not incriminatory).

We will conduct a one-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) with contextual information as the independent variable, proportion of incriminating misinterpretations as the dependent variable, and English language proficiency (as measured by the LexTale scale) as a covariate. We will analyze Tukey’s post-hoc comparisons to determine differences in contextual information. There will be evidence of confirmation bias if participants who receive contextual information make more incriminating misinterpretations than participants who receive no contextual information. We will also calculate Bayes factors to determine which competing hypothesis has more support.

q21.value:
We will use the conventional p < .05 criteria to determine whether the ANOVA and the subsequent post-hoc tests suggest that the results are significantly different from what would be expected if the null hypothesis were true. Tukey's post-hoc test accounts for multiple comparisons. 

We will also analyze Bayes factors, using a Bayes factor of 3 or more as evidence that confirmation bias affects people's interpretations of degraded audio recordings.

q22.value:
We will use five attention checks throughout the experiment (i.e., simple math problems) to ensure that participants are focused. Participants who fail to correctly respond to at least 3 of the attention check questions will be excluded from analyses. Additionally, participants who incorrectly respond to the manipulation check question which asks them to indicate the information they received about the recordings at the beginning of the experiment will be excluded from analyses. 

Participants who score below 50% on the LexTale will be excluded from analyses as well. 

Data that is 3 or more standard deviations above or below the mean will be considered outliers. If including outliers in statistical analyses does not change the overall data pattern, we will include them in our analyses. If including outliers changes the overall data pattern, we will exclude outliers from analyses.

q23.value: If more than 10% of a participant's data is missing (i.e., they fail to transcribe 5 or more of the 48 statements), their data will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value: In addition to coding participants’ incriminating misinterpretations, we will also code their accurate interpretations (i.e., they accurately identified every word in a given statement) as well as their non-incriminating interpretations (i.e., they incorrectly identify one or more words in a given statement such that their transcription is not incriminatory). We will conduct two additional one-way ANOVAs with contextual information as the independent variable and accurate interpretations and non-incriminating interpretations as the dependent variables.

attributes.title: Effects of adolescent co-use of alcohol and THC on prefrontal cortex GSK-3 signaling and working memory in rats.

q1.value: Effects of adolescent co-use of alcohol and THC on prefrontal cortex GSK-3 signaling and working memory in rats.

q2.value: Lauren Carrica, Joshua Michael Gulley, Asia Banks, Nu-Chu Liang, David Tkac

q3.value:
This study aims to identify the role of altered Akt/GSK-3 signaling in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) and subsequent functional deficits that are induced by co-use of alcohol and THC during adolescence. In order to accomplish this, we will use a rat model to investigate the effects of co-use of alcohol and THC during adolescence on working memory and on the expression and post-translational modification (PTM) of protein kinase B (Akt) and glycogen synthase kinase 3 beta (GSK-3β). 


To assess behavioral effects of adolescent use of alcohol and THC alone, as well as the co-use of alcohol and THC, we will assess the impact of drug exposure on performance of a delayed matching to position (DMTP) task that provides a measure of working memory. Following testing at short (0, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8s) and long (0, 2, 4, 8, 12, 18, 24s) delays, behavioral flexibility will be tested by requiring rats to reverse their strategy to delayed non-matching to-position (DNMTP) task. Performance on these tasks at several stages of the task will be evaluated. 


At the conclusion of behavioral testing, western blot analysis will be performed in order to examine protein expression and PTM differences in adolescent-exposed animals.

q4.value:
Previous work in both preclinical models and humans has demonstrated that exposure to either alcohol or THC alone can lead to many adverse consequences, including deficits in learning, behavioral flexibility, and attention (Gulley and Juraska, 2013, Neuroscience 249: 3-20; Rubino and Parolaro, 2016, Biol Psychiatry 79: 578-585; Staples and Mandyam, 2016, Front Psychiatry 7: 162). In addition, co-use of these drugs is relatively common in adolescents (Johnson et al, 2015, Ann Arbor, MI: Institute for Social Research) and is associated with more detrimental outcomes than use of either drug separately (Subbaraman and Kerr, 2015, Alcohol Clin Exp Res 39: 872-879; Hartman et al, 2016, Drug Test Anal 8: 690-701). We hypothesize that rats previously exposed to both alcohol and THC in adolescence will exhibit reduced accuracy on the longer delays of the DMTP task (when cognitive load is at its greatest) and increase the number of sessions needed to reach criterion, relative to both controls and rats exposed to either alcohol or THC alone. Additionally, much like in our work with amphetamines (Sherill et al, 2013, Behav Brain Res 242: 84-94) we expect that animals exposed to either alcohol or THC will be more susceptible to proactive interference and that animals exposed to a combination of alcohol and THC will exhibit the greatest deficits.  In light of previous reports of more significant effects of adolescent drug exposure in females (Lovelace et al. 2015, Neuropharmacology 99: 242-255); Rubino et al. 2008, Neuropsychopharmacology 33: 2760-2771), we hypothesize that the expected differences described above will be more emphasized in females than in males.  


Consistent with what has been shown in the literature (Ozaita et al. 2007, J Neurochem 102:1105-1114), we expect that phosphorylated Akt (pAkt) and phosphorylated GSK-3β (pGSK-3β) protein levels will differ in animals exposed to a combination of alcohol and THC. Specifically, as a consequence of chronic CB1 activation by THC and indirect CB1 activation by alcohol, we hypothesize that Akt and GSK-3β phosphorylation will be reduced, indicating decreased Akt activity and increased GSK-3β activity, respectively. Sex-specific differences in Akt/GSK-3 signaling following adolescent exposure to alcohol and THC remain largely unexplored. However, findings by Rubino and Parolaro (2016, Biol Psychiatry 79: 578-585) show variation in cannabinoid metabolism between sexes and suggest that Akt/GSK-3 dysregulation will be more prominent in female rats.

q11.value:
Data collection for an initial cohort (24 rats, 3 per treatment group per sex) began on 12/9/19. Bodyweights and voluntary consumption of saccharin vehicle and 10% ethanol will be measured. The data were recorded such that bodyweight can later be analyzed, and for weight-dependent dosing of THC. Discovery of unconsumed THC cookies between dosing sessions was also noted and evaluated for possible data exclusion purposes. Training on the behavioral test have been recorded to ensure successful progression through the training steps up through and including the forced choice stage detailed in our methods. Data for this initial cohort will be analyzed upon completion of behavioral testing in order to confirm methodology for the following cohorts. 


Data collection for up to 3 more cohorts will not begin until after collection of the initial cohort has ended.

question.value:
Litters of rats will be ordered from Envigo to arrive at our colony at approximately postnatal day (P)24. Each cohort will consist of multiple litters (up to 36 rats) with the same date of birth (± 2 days).  A complete description of the data collection procedures and other methods for this study are included in the supplementary document in the pre-registration on the OSF site.  Briefly, rats undergo drug (or vehicle) exposure from P28-P47, their working memory and behavioral flexibility is assessed from approximately P60 until P111, and they are finally euthanized and their brains are removed for later analysis of protein expression and PTM. 


Exclusion Criteria
Rats assigned to THC groups may not consume THC-laced cookies at doses higher than 3 mg/kg within the 15 min period during which they are presented. In these cases, which in our experience are relatively rare, total mg/kg of unconsumed THC will be used as an exclusion criterion.  All data for a given rat will be removed from the analysis if either of these conditions is met:  

(1) the rat consumes less than 85 mg/kg of the cumulative THC dose during the entirety of the treatment (targeted cumulative dose = 114 mg/kg) 
-OR-
(2) the rat consumes two or fewer of the cookies presented to it during the last four days of the drug exposure period   

A cookie and its associated THC dose will be considered unconsumed if any portion of it remains at the next scheduled time for cookie presentation.   

There also may be instances where data are excluded as a result of technical problems.  Most typically, these include mechanical failures of levers, sensors, lights, or pellet feeders. In instances of mechanical failure during the training stages (see Table 2, supplemental methods), only data when this event occurs will be excluded from the analysis; the rat will be run on a repeat of that training session later in the same day. If a mechanical failure occurs during the testing stages, that day’s data will be omitted and the rat will be run the following day as though the omitted day had not taken place (e.g. if the rat was running on DMTP session 4 during the failure, it will run DMTP session 4 the following day). All data from other sessions for the affected rat will be included. 

Western blot testing for proteins of interest will only be performed if antibodies of appropriate specificity are available at the time of analysis.

q13.value: The planned sample size per group (8 groups total, e.g. vehicle/vehicle-treated adolescent male) is up to 12 rats (see stopping rule below), for a total sample size of up to 96 rats.

q14.value:
A priori power analyses conducted in G*Power 3.1 using estimates of the effect size (Cohen’s f = 0.2-0.3) from published results of similar paradigms (Sherrill et all, 2013, Behav Brain Res 242: 84-94), alpha = 0.05, and power = 0.80, suggest n’s per group of 7-9 rats.  We have decided to collect data from up to 96 total rats (n=12/group) in order to accommodate potential attrition due to refusal to self-administer as well as individual learning differences on the behavioral task that could cause an animal to fail to successfully learn during early training stages in a timely matter (e.g. a rat that does not learn to lever press).  

Screenshots of our power analyses in G*Power 3.1 have been uploaded to our OSF project website.

q15.value:
Data collection will be terminated after three total cohorts, if no changes are made to the design or methods following the initial cohort AND sample sizes of at least 9 per group have been achieved.   

A fourth cohort will be used in the experiment if EITHER the initial cohort is not included in analyses due to changes in design or methods that are driven by a majority of animals from any group not meeting performance criterion within the set number of sessions; OR if sample sizes of at least 9 per group have not been achieved at the end of three cohorts. 

Our stopping rule decision tree has been uploaded to the OSF project site.

question.value: Our manipulated variables include treatment (4 levels: vehicle/vehicle, THC/vehicle, vehicle/alcohol, and THC/alcohol) and sex. When analyzing by delay, delay is an additional manipulated variable.

During drug exposure sessions, intake of THC and ethanol will be recorded.  

During DMTP and DNMTP (and all training leading up to these tasks), lever presses, trough entries, nosepokes, omissions, and rewards earned will be recorded on a computer running Graphic State 4.1.13 software. 

Western blot proteins will be visualized with chemiluminescent probes using a Bio-Rad ChemiDoc Imager, and visualized bands will be quantified using area and pixel values calculated by the National Institutes of Health’s image processor, ImageJ.

Voluntary consumption of 10% ethanol will be measured by estimating the dose consumed (g/kg) with a conservative formula: [(ethanol concentration × fluid intake in grams × ethanol density) ÷ body weight in kg] = [(0.1 × fluid intake in grams × 0.789) ÷ body weight in kg]. Daily fluid intake for saccharin vehicle and 10% ethanol solutions will be calculated by subtracting the final weight of the administered sipper tubes from the initial weight taken at the start of each 2.5 hour session. 

Percent correct choices for DMTP and DNMTP sessions will be analyzed separately for each delay and collapsed across delay, with the latter used to determine whether criterion performance is met. Proactive interference will be measured as accuracy on a trial by trial basis, such that accuracy on “same” trials (the correct lever for the current trial is the same as the previous trial) will be compared to accuracy on “different” trials. Number of omissions will also be analyzed separately for each delay and collapsed across delay.

Matching to Position, no delay (MTP): Three-way, mixed factor ANOVA with sex and treatment as the between subjects factors and session as the within subjects factor will be conducted to analyze performance across sessions. 

Delayed Matching to Position (DMTP) and Delayed Non-Matching to Position (DNMTP): Performance during DMTP and DNMTP sessions will be analyzed using a mixed ANOVA with sex and treatment as the between subjects factors and session and/or delay as the within subject factor(s). For proactive interference analysis, sex and treatment will serve as between-subject factors and the previous trial result (“same” or “different”, as described above) as the within-subject factor.  

Optical density data obtained via western blot will be normalized to a global control to allow for comparison between sexes. The relative intensities of proteins of interest will then be determined using housekeeping protein vinculin or against total target protein expression. Resulting intensities will be analyzed using two-way ANOVA with treatment and sex as the between-subjects factors.

q21.value: We will use the alpha level of 0.05 as our criterion to make inferences in our statistical analyses. All tests will be two-tailed, and Bonferroni's correction will be used to correct for multiple testing error (If necessary).

registration_responses.q1: Effects of adolescent co-use of alcohol and THC on prefrontal cortex GSK-3 signaling and working memory in rats.
registration_responses.q2: Lauren Carrica, Joshua Michael Gulley, Asia Banks, Nu-Chu Liang, David Tkac
registration_responses.q3:
This study aims to identify the role of altered Akt/GSK-3 signaling in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) and subsequent functional deficits that are induced by co-use of alcohol and THC during adolescence. In order to accomplish this, we will use a rat model to investigate the effects of co-use of alcohol and THC during adolescence on working memory and on the expression and post-translational modification (PTM) of protein kinase B (Akt) and glycogen synthase kinase 3 beta (GSK-3β). 


To assess behavioral effects of adolescent use of alcohol and THC alone, as well as the co-use of alcohol and THC, we will assess the impact of drug exposure on performance of a delayed matching to position (DMTP) task that provides a measure of working memory. Following testing at short (0, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8s) and long (0, 2, 4, 8, 12, 18, 24s) delays, behavioral flexibility will be tested by requiring rats to reverse their strategy to delayed non-matching to-position (DNMTP) task. Performance on these tasks at several stages of the task will be evaluated. 


At the conclusion of behavioral testing, western blot analysis will be performed in order to examine protein expression and PTM differences in adolescent-exposed animals.

q2.value: Dev Patel, William Murdock, John Conlon, Spencer Kwon

q3.value: In the United States, large educational achievement gaps between groups (socioeconomic status, race, etc.) contribute to large gaps in poverty rates and other long-term economic outcomes. Simultaneously, there are also large gaps in education “inputs,” with a strong correlation between study hours and academic performance. We examine the drivers of this variation by directly measuring students’ beliefs and preferences about the education production function. Further, we investigate how these beliefs and preferences respond to a low-cost information intervention. We hope the evidence our study provides will help inform policy makers in their strive to reduce observed achievement gaps across socioeconomic statuses.

q4.value:
We have three different information treatment groups (in addition to a control group). Each treatment is designed to affect a certain aspect of students’ preferences/beliefs (these treatments are described in the “Study Design” section below. The hypotheses we hope to test include:

1. The GPA vs Study Hours treatment will affect students’ beliefs about the effectiveness of their studying (i.e. the likelihood that their grades will be D, C, B, or A conditional on the number of hours they spend studying). 

2. The GPA vs Educational Attainment treatment will affect students’ preferences for grades. That is, it will change the number of study hours they would be willing to put in for better grades.

3. The Social Life vs Study Hours treatment will affect students’ preferences for grades. That is, it will change the amount of money students would have to be paid to increase their study hours.

4. All treatments will affect students intended/expected/reported study hours and academic outcomes. We expect these effects to be larger if the effects on students’ preferences and beliefs are larger.

The direction of all these effects will depend in large part on students’ prior beliefs about the information we provide students. If, for example, students tend to believe that the link between studying and grades is less strong than it in fact is, then we would expect the information to increase their beliefs about the effectiveness of their own studying.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Our study design is primarily a between-subjects design. We hope to examine the persistence of any impacts our experiment has on beliefs and preferences in a follow-up observational survey of the same students several months after the initial round. 

Our experiment has four conditions. In all conditions, we collect novel measures of students’ beliefs and preferences about the education production function. The variation across the treatment arms is described below:

1. Control: Students are not given any information.

2. GPA vs Study Hours Information: Students are given information about average study levels in nationally representative data and how this correlates with cumulative high school GPA. 

3. GPA vs Educational Attainment Information: Students are given information about the cumulative high school GPA in nationally representative data and how this correlates with educational attainment.

4. Social Life vs Study Hours Information: Students are given information about the cumulative high school GPA in nationally representative data and how this correlates with the amount of time students spend with friends.

Each student will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. Each condition has counterbalancing -- the order of modules within the survey are randomized to control for order effects. When appropriate, we also randomize the order of question choices to mitigate any order effects that may arise during item selection.

q9.value: Participants will be randomized into conditions at the individual-level through logic built into our Qualtrics survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.

CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.

CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.

For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: The sample size of our study will be approximately 4,360 students -- 1,090 students will be assigned to each condition. The exact sample size is determined based off of the response rate of students who participate in CLRN’s sample.

q14.value: Given an alpha of 0.05, the above sample size will provide exactly 80.0% power to detect an effect size of d = 0.12 for any pairwise difference. CLRN chose an expected effect size of 0.12 based off of a review of educational RCTs and recent RCTs that were conducted on their network.

question.value:
The experimental design described above aims to manipulate students’ reported beliefs and preferences about the education production function. Specifically, we will measure:
Beliefs about the study habits of a nationally representative sample of high school students

-- How much respondents value studying*
-- How much respondents value grades*
-- How much respondents think studying impacts the grades they will get*

Throughout the study, students will have the questions framed as a specific class to increase comprehension and relatability. We will ask students to either consider their math course or their English course, and a given student will see the same framing throughout the entire survey. Which framing a student sees is randomly determined with equal chance. The starred (*) variables above are impacted by the framing of the questions and are specific to the given subject (i.e., math or English).

We describe below how we transform specific survey items to create measures of how much respondents value studying and grades and how much they think studying impacts the grades they will get.

In addition to the above variables, we will also measure: 

-- Respondents’ ability on practice percent chance questions
-- How many hours they expect to study this semester and next semester*
-- What grades they expect to get this semester and next semester*
-- Uncertainty about elicited beliefs
-- How they spend an average hour studying*
-- A measure of procrastination
-- How much influence their parents have in their study habits
-- How many hours their parents want them to study*
-- How much they think other students at their school and their closest friends study*
-- How many hours they would study if they could control that number*
-- The salary of 40-year-olds who had various GPAs in high school.
-- The salary of 4-year college graduates vs. non-graduates
-- How much they think studying impacts popularity

As described above, the starred (*) variables above are impacted by the framing of the questions and are specific to the given subject (i.e., math or English).

We will link also link our survey responses to administrative data on grades and student information provided by CLRN.

We currently do not know what specific variables the schools’ administrative data will contain. However, if multiple variables are included that could be used to classify the socioeconomic status (SES) of students (e.g., parental income, race, free and reduced price lunch status, ELL status), we would combine them into an SES index. Obviously our exact decisions depend on what variables the data contains. But we will make all available variables known and try to replicate SES indices that are commonly found in the literature. To the extent there are multiple decisions we must make to construct this index, we will conduct robustness checks to fully understand how these decisions impact our conclusions.

We will use a standard intent-to-treat (ITT) framework to investigate how treatment assignment impacts the manipulated variables discussed above. The baseline specification using no controls will be reported, but additional specifications which include standard control variables (e.g., gender, age, subject, school fixed-effects) will also be reported. Including these variables will help control for differences in the outcome variable that are not due to treatment assignment and will further increase the power and precision of our analysis.

As secondary heterogeneity analyses, we will use similar specifications to investigate whether treatment impacts vary across student groups. For example, we plan to investigate if treatment effects vary by gender, SES, race, subject questions were framed as (English vs. Math), and ability of students.

q20.value:
To measure preferences, we constructed a telescoping price lists that capture how much students value studying and grades. Price lists are common experimental methods to determine respondents’ indifference points between two options. We will assign final valuations to the midpoints between students’ closest accepted and refused offers (robustness checks will investigate other assignment choices) in the price lists. For students who always/never accept, we will top code according to the following rule: 
-- For these students, we ask an additional follow up question that directly elicits their valuation of the given grade or study hours. We will use these responses as students’ valuations, but we will top code the reported numbers at the 95th percentile that we observe in our data.
 
To measure how much individuals think studying impacts their grades, we constructed a matrix of study hours and grades. We ask students what they think the chances are they will receive a certain grade in a class if they study a certain number of hours each. We ask these questions for 0, 2, 4, and 6 hours of studying. See the example provided above. Thus, transforming these responses to returns to studying is straightforward. In our simple baseline model, we will assume linearity across these study hours and consider a student’s perceived return to studying as the slope. Robustness checks will consider other parameterizations (e.g., quadratic, cubic) to better capture diminishing/negative returns.

registration_responses.q2: Dev Patel, William Murdock, John Conlon, Spencer Kwon
registration_responses.q3: In the United States, large educational achievement gaps between groups (socioeconomic status, race, etc.) contribute to large gaps in poverty rates and other long-term economic outcomes. Simultaneously, there are also large gaps in education “inputs,” with a strong correlation between study hours and academic performance. We examine the drivers of this variation by directly measuring students’ beliefs and preferences about the education production function. Further, we investigate how these beliefs and preferences respond to a low-cost information intervention. We hope the evidence our study provides will help inform policy makers in their strive to reduce observed achievement gaps across socioeconomic statuses.
registration_responses.q4:
We have three different information treatment groups (in addition to a control group). Each treatment is designed to affect a certain aspect of students’ preferences/beliefs (these treatments are described in the “Study Design” section below. The hypotheses we hope to test include:

1. The GPA vs Study Hours treatment will affect students’ beliefs about the effectiveness of their studying (i.e. the likelihood that their grades will be D, C, B, or A conditional on the number of hours they spend studying). 

2. The GPA vs Educational Attainment treatment will affect students’ preferences for grades. That is, it will change the number of study hours they would be willing to put in for better grades.

3. The Social Life vs Study Hours treatment will affect students’ preferences for grades. That is, it will change the amount of money students would have to be paid to increase their study hours.

4. All treatments will affect students intended/expected/reported study hours and academic outcomes. We expect these effects to be larger if the effects on students’ preferences and beliefs are larger.

The direction of all these effects will depend in large part on students’ prior beliefs about the information we provide students. If, for example, students tend to believe that the link between studying and grades is less strong than it in fact is, then we would expect the information to increase their beliefs about the effectiveness of their own studying.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomized into conditions at the individual-level through logic built into our Qualtrics survey.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: The sample size of our study will be approximately 4,360 students -- 1,090 students will be assigned to each condition. The exact sample size is determined based off of the response rate of students who participate in CLRN’s sample.
registration_responses.q14: Given an alpha of 0.05, the above sample size will provide exactly 80.0% power to detect an effect size of d = 0.12 for any pairwise difference. CLRN chose an expected effect size of 0.12 based off of a review of educational RCTs and recent RCTs that were conducted on their network.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Our study design is primarily a between-subjects design. We hope to examine the persistence of any impacts our experiment has on beliefs and preferences in a follow-up observational survey of the same students several months after the initial round. 

Our experiment has four conditions. In all conditions, we collect novel measures of students’ beliefs and preferences about the education production function. The variation across the treatment arms is described below:

1. Control: Students are not given any information.

2. GPA vs Study Hours Information: Students are given information about average study levels in nationally representative data and how this correlates with cumulative high school GPA. 

3. GPA vs Educational Attainment Information: Students are given information about the cumulative high school GPA in nationally representative data and how this correlates with educational attainment.

4. Social Life vs Study Hours Information: Students are given information about the cumulative high school GPA in nationally representative data and how this correlates with the amount of time students spend with friends.

Each student will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. Each condition has counterbalancing -- the order of modules within the survey are randomized to control for order effects. When appropriate, we also randomize the order of question choices to mitigate any order effects that may arise during item selection.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.

CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.

CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.

For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The experimental design described above aims to manipulate students’ reported beliefs and preferences about the education production function. Specifically, we will measure:
Beliefs about the study habits of a nationally representative sample of high school students

-- How much respondents value studying*
-- How much respondents value grades*
-- How much respondents think studying impacts the grades they will get*

Throughout the study, students will have the questions framed as a specific class to increase comprehension and relatability. We will ask students to either consider their math course or their English course, and a given student will see the same framing throughout the entire survey. Which framing a student sees is randomly determined with equal chance. The starred (*) variables above are impacted by the framing of the questions and are specific to the given subject (i.e., math or English).

We describe below how we transform specific survey items to create measures of how much respondents value studying and grades and how much they think studying impacts the grades they will get.
registration_responses.q17.question:
In addition to the above variables, we will also measure: 

-- Respondents’ ability on practice percent chance questions
-- How many hours they expect to study this semester and next semester*
-- What grades they expect to get this semester and next semester*
-- Uncertainty about elicited beliefs
-- How they spend an average hour studying*
-- A measure of procrastination
-- How much influence their parents have in their study habits
-- How many hours their parents want them to study*
-- How much they think other students at their school and their closest friends study*
-- How many hours they would study if they could control that number*
-- The salary of 40-year-olds who had various GPAs in high school.
-- The salary of 4-year college graduates vs. non-graduates
-- How much they think studying impacts popularity

As described above, the starred (*) variables above are impacted by the framing of the questions and are specific to the given subject (i.e., math or English).

We will link also link our survey responses to administrative data on grades and student information provided by CLRN.
registration_responses.q18.question: We currently do not know what specific variables the schools’ administrative data will contain. However, if multiple variables are included that could be used to classify the socioeconomic status (SES) of students (e.g., parental income, race, free and reduced price lunch status, ELL status), we would combine them into an SES index. Obviously our exact decisions depend on what variables the data contains. But we will make all available variables known and try to replicate SES indices that are commonly found in the literature. To the extent there are multiple decisions we must make to construct this index, we will conduct robustness checks to fully understand how these decisions impact our conclusions.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use a standard intent-to-treat (ITT) framework to investigate how treatment assignment impacts the manipulated variables discussed above. The baseline specification using no controls will be reported, but additional specifications which include standard control variables (e.g., gender, age, subject, school fixed-effects) will also be reported. Including these variables will help control for differences in the outcome variable that are not due to treatment assignment and will further increase the power and precision of our analysis.

As secondary heterogeneity analyses, we will use similar specifications to investigate whether treatment impacts vary across student groups. For example, we plan to investigate if treatment effects vary by gender, SES, race, subject questions were framed as (English vs. Math), and ability of students.
